titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. Rose at half past six.— Read in Schubert’s second volume the Chapters on Refraction and Parallax— They occupied me all the reading part of the day: that is untill half-past three P.M. from which untill dinner time, is now my walking hour. After dinner I find it vain to attempt reading, and at 9 I finished the Evening.— Refraction and Parallax are dry studies— They require occasional
intervals of remission to my attention— So I looked into Shakespear’s Henry 4. Act 2. Scene 1. where the Carrier concludes that it is “four by the day, because Charles’ wain is over the new Chimney”— The time of this scene must have been in winter, and the usage of the Common Carrier’s of that time to judge of the time of the Night by the position of the Great Bear. I looked also in Pliny for the references to Epigenes, so differently cited by Goguet and Schubert.— The difference is between 720, and 720,000.— Poinsinet gives in the text and translates it 720. but he says in a note that it should be 720,000—so that the question remains unsolved.

2. Half past five. The incidents of the day are so like the general tenor of my time, that they need not be noticed— Mr Bayard spent the Evening with us— The remainder of the day I was engaged in reading— Finished the Book of Job— I believe this to be a moral tale—a fictitious history; nor do I perceive any article of faith, necessarily depending upon its reality.— The Book is supposed to have been written by Moses; which may very possibly be true; but its whole tenor—narrative—dialogue—and personages has to me the appearance of a story adapted to a doctrine, and not of a doctrine resulting from a Story.— The appearance of Satan, among the sons of God, before the Lord in the first Chapter, and the Conversation between the Lord and him, has not the air of History— The four Messengers who come to Job, to announce his disasters in one identical form of words— The three friends who come to comfort him, and sit down with him seven days and seven Nights without speaking a word— The incidents at the conclusion of the story; every incident, as well as every discourse betokens the work of the Imagination, and not the record of facts— The doctrine which they teach is the purest and sublimest morality— The question which they discuss the most difficult in the whole compass of moral philosophy.— Job, the perfect and upright man, is permitted by the divine will to be visited with the severest afflictions, to be plunged in an instant from the summit of prosperity to the lowest depth of wretchedness, as a trial of his integrity— His wife advises him to renounce it, which he indignantly refuses— His friends, infer from his misfortunes, that he is punished for his iniquities—or that he complains unjustly for sufferings which arise merely from the lot of humanity.— He vindicates his own integrity; but he dwells too confidently upon it— He complains that there is no destruction of Heavenly favour to reward him for it— That God destroyeth the perfect, and the wicked— He is righteous in his own eyes— Elihu first blames Job, for justifying himself rather than God—and he blames his friends, for condemming him without proof— At last the Lord, out of the whirl wind, confounds the reasoning of Job, by recalling to his mind, his impotence, even to conceive the purposes, and the infinite extent of the divine power— Job is instantly convinced of his error, and repents with the deepest humility— He is restored to the divine favour; and his friends are commanded to atone for their uncharitable sentiments concerning him, by sacrifices.— The moral doctrines taught by this Story are,—1. The omnipotence and the Justice of the divine Government. 2. That the afflictions of the righteous, are trials of their Integrity. 3. The frailty and infirmity of man. and 4. The duties of resignation to God’s will, and of humility under affliction— These are all Hebrew doctrines— They are in no antient system of mythology, and in none of the philosophical systems of the Greeks— They are inculcated with great ingenuity and energy; and the story is framed to present them in their greatest possible force— I lament being unable to read this Book in the original— All the translations are defective, and the English one particularly and greatly incorrect— Many passages present to my mind no distinct sense—many such disjointed and incoherent ideas, as could never be put together by a man of genius like the author of Job. Sentences, one half of which have no apparent relation to the other— Violent and unnatural transitions of thought; and obscurities which it is vain to attempt bringing to light.— There is scarcely any difference between the discourses of the three friends, in point of substance— Their phrases and imagery are varied; but they all dwell upon the same leading ideas— There is nothing but the names, to discriminate the one from the other— There is no individuality among them, as there is in all the historical personages of the Bible: and this is one of the reasons upon which I believe the narrative fictitious— Compare it with the Stories of Ruth, or of Esther—with those of any of the Patriarchs, Judges, Kings, or Prophets, and how clearly you see the difference between a portrait from the life, and a fancy-piece!— Job is a philosophical Romance, full of profound and admirable instruction; nor do I suppose it more necessary to believe it a history of facts, than to believe the Parables of the prodigal son, or of the good Samaritan to have been so.— I also read this day in Schubert’s Astronomy, on the size and figure of the Earth, and its daily and annual Revolutions.— He explains very fully the modern method of measuring a degree of the meridian, and refers to Bradley’s discoveries of Nutation and aberration; while he was seeking the yearly parallax of the fixed Stars.

3. IV.45. After reading about four hours,—I walked round by the lower Admiralty before Breakfast— And I walked again before dinner— Mr Todd spent about an hour of the Evening here— I proceeded in the perusal of Schubert’s Popular Astronomy; and read the Chapter concerning the movements of the fixed Stars. The Copernican system has been so corroborated by the discoveries of later Astronomers that it has almost become a heresy to recollect that it is still only a system— A theory, devised by man to account for the appearances in the Heavens. I am not appalled either by the distances or by the multitudes of the fixed stars which this system and the observations of the improved Telescope present to the mind; for space is infinite, and however great the multitude of worlds may be, he who created and governs, can number them though I cannot.— But as the whole system of Copernicus is founded on the fundamental axiom that every appearance to us of the Heavenly Bodies is a combination of optical delusions, the question occurs, whether, there may not be yet other optical delusions, not yet detected, but which if discovered would produce a totally new and different theory of Astronomy. The objection to the Copernican system that it implies a great waste of unoccupied space between our solar system and the nearest fixed Star, Mr Schubert does not satisfactorily answer— His conjecture that there are millions of Planets and Comets revolving round our Sun is mere guess-work not supported by any observation— That the Planets and Comets may be more than we know is highly probable; but that there are many more, I see no reason for believing. The inference from the flattening of the Globe at the Poles it was once a fluid is also mere conjecture, and the argument in support of it weak— There is a part of this Book which for want of proper Mathematical knowledge, I do not understand.

4. IV.55. Morning walk in the rain— About 2 afternoon I crossed the river in a Boat, and went to Mr Fishwick’s to fetch Charles home— But he was gone upon a visit to Mrs Brown’s; whose son is one of his schoolmates— I therefore returned without him, and took my second walk.— Mr Smith dined with Mr Lewis— Miss Frederica Bode was here in the Evening— I read in Schubert the Chapters on the true Solar System, and on the Theory of the eccentric Circle, in the Section upon the true movements of the Planets— The whole Ptolemean theory of the eccentric Circle, the epicycles, and the equalizing cycles is here unfolded— The Tychonian System is barely noticed, and the Copernican system is explained and defended.— I turned over a few leaves of Petau’s Doctrina Temporum, and looked into 2d: Vol. Jortin’s Remarks on Ecclesiastical History.

5. IV:30 Mr Slade called on me this morning, and had some conversation with me, about his desire of being presented at Court, which has become an ardent Passion— I mentioned to him the only obstacle of which I was aware, and expressed my readiness to present him if it could be done consistently with the established rules— He said he was acquainted with Count Romanzoff, and offered to apply himself to him, to ascertain whether he might not be indulged with this favour, to which I readily assented— Mr Harris spent part of the Evening with us. I read Prayers for the second Sunday in Advent, and Massillon’s Sermon for that day—Upon afflictions. It was preached before Louis 14. in the time of his afflictions; not long before his death— He addresses him personally according to the custom of French Preachers, and I am sorry to say flatters him grossly— The discourse in other respects a very good one, and teaches the proper use of affliction—taking away the pretexts by which our prevarications would urge to exempt us from its salutary operation— I also read further in Schubert’s Astronomy.

6. V. At Noon I attended with Mr Smith at the Winter Palace, where the Empresses held a Court; it being St: Catherine’s day. The Empress-Mother was in a transport of enchantment, at the flourishing state of affairs; and the assembly of têtes couronnées, at Frankfort on the Mein— Mr Todd was here in the Evening, and untill one in the Morning. I retired myself at Midnight.— This morning I read in Schubert the Chapter on Comets, and the first Chapter on the secondary Planets— In the Evening I looked into the volume, upon Comets published at Boston, and which Judge Davis sent me.— I spoke at the Circle this day to General Betancourt, about the Mathematical Course of La Croix, which he has had reprinted here for the use of the students at the institution, and of which he promised to furnish me with a copy.

7. VIII:30. A consequence of the late Evening of last Night. I sent to General Betancourt for the Volumes of La Croix, which he had promised me, and received them from him— They are elementary treatises of Arithmetic, Geometry, Algebra, Trigonometry, Calcul differential, and calcul integral— Read in Schubert the remaining Chapters on the secondary Planets, and that on Saturn’s Ring. And in the Evening I read Dr Winthrop’s first lecture on Comets. I made the Evening shorter, because the last had been too long. I have begun a course of occupation which will require not a little perseverance.

8. IV:50. I finished reading the second Volume of Schubert—containing his Theoretic Astronomy. It closes with the Chapters on eclipses, occultations and transits.— My mind and heart are too much bent upon this pursuit, and my health already sinks under the anxiety of my application to it— I was awake nearly two hours this morning before I rose, and my capacity of study was proportionably affected by it— I walked before Breakfast, and again before dinner; and in the Evening with Mrs: Adams paid visits to Baron Klinkowström and his Lady; General Betancourt, and the Duke de Serra Capriola— Baron Klinkowström is a Swedish Officer married to an English Lady, whom we have met at Count Romanzoff’s— They were not at home— At General Betancourt’s, and afterwards at the Duke’s we met Mr Littleton, and English Gentleman, and his wife Lady Sarah Littleton, a daughter of Lord Spencer— At the Duke’s also came in while we were there Baroness Stoganoff, Countess Gerebzoff, Miss Bussy, and several other Ladies— The Duke himself was not at home— At General Betancourt’s we were told of the capitulation of Dantzig, which Mr Littleton disapproved as too favourable to the French; also of great distress, consternation, and failures at Paris— Don Francisco Colombi was also at the Generals.— We came home about ten.

9. IV:30. After a very restless Night, and two hours of watching before I rose— Morning visit from Mr Montreal.— I began reading the third Volume of Schubert’s work, containing the Physical Astronomy— The first and second Chapters concern the extent and distances of the Heavenly Bodies, and of the Solar System particularly. The author here estimates at a million the number of Comets belonging to our system, and attempts to support his estimate by an argument— But whenever Mr Schubert substitutes hypotheses for ascertained facts he is inclined to a scale of things too large for my understanding— In general I am surprized to find how little we yet know of Astronomy, and particularly of the Comets— The prediction by Halley of the return of the Comet of 1682 in 1758 was very exactly verified, but that fact stands yet alone— The Comet of 1661. which Halley supposed would return in 1789 or 1790 did not make its appearance at the appointed time, and that of 1770 the calculated period of which was 5 1/2 years Schubert speaks of as a riddle— Altogether the theory of Comets needs a larger stock of observed facts, and another Genius like Newton or Kepler to be well understood— I looked into the Arithmetic and the Algebra of La Croix; read Dr Winthrop’s second Lecture on Comets and the Appendix; and the Article on the Calendar in the French Encylopaedia, which I borrowed of Mr Montreal— In the Evening I was too much over come with weariness for study, and retired, after a foot-bath about ten.

10. IV:45. After a very good Night’s rest— Miss Frederica Bode dined and spent part of the Evening with us— Mr Bayard was afterwards here, but I had already retired to bed. The clouds that have hung over the atmosphere these six weeks, almost without intermission were this morning partly withdrawn— I saw therefore Jupiter in the Meridian, and the Moon after she had passed it— Walked before breakfast to observe them in the open sky— The perusal of Schubert has made me ashamed of my ignorance of the most remarkable objects and most ordinary movements of the sky— But the day and Evening were again cloudy.— I read the Chapter on the extent of the universe, and part of that on the topography of the Heavens. His 3000 milky ways, and his stars from which light has been millions of years coming to us appear to me foolish fancies.—incredulus odi— The conjecture that the nebula in the sword of Orion is the great central body of our system of fixed stars, is not much better— The topographical chapter is excessively meagre in the collection of facts— The movements, periods and orbits of the Planets appear after all to comprize the whole of human discoveries, in Astronomy— Even their sizes and distances remain is some degree problematical.— The most remarkable new fact that I find is that of the rotation of the secondary Planets upon their axis coincident with their revolution round their primary Planes, which makes their movements not more complex than those of the primary Planets.— I read likewise part of Mr Oliver’s Essay on Comets— But my Chronology lingers too much— The weather grows cold, and the river is full of ice.

11. V. After an hour’s watching. I walked before Breakfast round by the lower Admiralty, and found the river was closed—and the workmen were preparing the Bridge which they have adopted from that used by the French at the passage of the Beresino— Before dinner I went round again and found it was finished and the people already passing— I went over it my self to Mr Fishwick’s for Charles; but he was already gone— Mrs Adams had sent Timofei over for him about a quarter of an hour before— I found him arrived when I came home— The day and Evening were partly clear so that I could look for stars; but many times in the course of the Evening the sky in the course of five minutes became totally overcast, and baffled my pursuit— I have had for several days, Jupiter in the Meridian just after I rise in the morning— This Evening I found Venus and Mars— I also nearly
ascertained by the directions in La Lande’s Abridgment, Arcturus, the keepers of the Pole-star, Capella, the Bull’s Horns, Sirius, Procyon, and Aldebaran—but not entirely beyond a doubt— After the Moon rose which was about 7 1/2 in the Evening the sky cleared away again, but her light, dimmed that of all the stars— I continued this morning the perusal of Schubert— Finished the Chapter on the Topography of the Heavens, and began the Division upon movements round a central body, and the Chapter upon Powers.— Here it is that the Newtonian theory is to be explained, and here again my Mathematical ignorance draws the veil before my mental eye.

12. IV:45. The morning was clear and cold, and I walked an hour before Breakfast. But the sky was afterwards soon overcast, and thus continued the remainder of the day and Evening. Mr Todd dined and spent part of the Evening with us. I read prayers for the third Sunday in Advent, and Massillon’s Sermon for the same day on the delay of Conversion, and that immediately preceding it; for the festival of the conception of the Virgin Mary, which is kept the 8th: of December— It is the best of the two; but the divisions of this preacher are so artificial and quaint that they remind one of goodman Threefold in the Drummer. The text of the Sermon upon the Conception is Exod. 3.3. Vadam et videbo visionem hanc magnam—I will turn aside, and see this great sight. What connection has this with the subject of the discourse? why, as the bush burnt without being consumed so Mary led a life of perfect purity, in the midst of a corrupt world. This Sermon however contains several keen and just remarks upon the manners of men, and some eloquent exhortations to virtue.

13. IV.30. The Calendar announces a conjunction of the Moon and Jupiter this day, which I hoped to have seen. They were both in the meridian between five and six this morning, but the sky was covered with clouds and neither of them was visible. Between 8 and 9 I took Charles over the Beresino Bridge to school, and I walked again before dinner— The usual domestic arrangements employed the rest of the Morning, and I gave the Evening to idleness— I am now reading the dryest and abstrusest part of Schubert’s Astronomy— The theory of gravitation—the reciprocal disturbances of the planetary spheres, and the problem of the three bodies— I am afraid this also will be time wasted, for it is reading in a language to which I am a stranger.

14. V. The weather has become severe; but I walk an hour before Breakfast, and an hour and a half before dinner— I called at the Bookseller Rospini’s to enquire if he had Bode’s Celestial Charts, but he had not, and told me they were not to be procured in this City. He shewed me a Berlin Catalogue which contained them, and many other astronomical publications of Bode and others. Mr Harris spent the Evening with us.— I am drawing towards the close of Schubert’s Book, and this day finished the Chapters on the perturbations of the Heavenly Bodies, and began the Division which treats of their Rotations— These are among the profoundest parts of the Book, and therefore among those from which I collect the fewest ideas.

15. V. As the morning was clear, I walked out with the expectation of seeing the Sun rise, and to mark now at the time of the Solstice the point of his greatest southern declination— But there was a heavy Cloud over that part of the horizon, and nothing was to be seen— Mr Lewis paid me a morning visit— I dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a company partly diplomatic— Madame Bardaxi was there—Lady Sarah Littleton, Madame de Klinkowström, and the Baroness de Koscull, a Swedish Lady just arrived; very beautiful, and about whom Captain Guedes, entertained me at table with some strange Stories— She sent Cards this morning to Mrs: Adams and I enquired of Mr Schulepoff, whether her husband was with her. He told me she was divorced, and Guedes said she had the reputation of a femme galante— Her manners were altogether of that character— I was seated at table between Mr Bardaxi, and Guedes— After dinner I had some conversation with Prince Kurakin, who told me he received visitors on Tuesday and Saturday Evenings— Neither the Duke de Serra Capriola, nor Count Maistre were there— I came home about 7 in the Evening— Reaumur’s thermometer was this day at -15.

16. V. I finished reading Schubert’s Popular Astronomy, and began to read the Abridgment of La Lande— The morning was clear, and I walked again to seek a spot for observing the rising and setting Sun— I found none however suitable to the purpose, and there was a thick cloud again before the Sun when he rose. I walked again at the time of the setting Sun, but without better success— We all dined at Mr Harris’s— Mr Bailey, the English Consul and his Lady, Dr Creichton and his Lady; Mr and Mrs and Miss Sally Krehmer; and Mrs Fisher were there; and with Messrs: Gallatins, Bayard, Milligan and Todd formed the Company— We came home between 9 and 10 in the Evening.

17. V.15. The morning was so nearly clear that I walked in search of a spot to mark the rising Sun, but he rose in a Cloud; and this City is built upon such a perfect level, that there is not I believe a spot in it where the eye can freely range to the horizon. After Breakfast I went to a Mr George Bauer, who has advertised in the Gazette a Tachymeter, or instrument for mensuration of heights and distances; as a new invention of his own, which has been approved and recommended by the imperial Committee of military Science; but he had none of them in a state of preparation— I thence went and called upon Mr: Meyer to make some further arrangement of my concerns at his disposal— Afterwards went to Weyher the Bookseller’s shop to enquire if he had Bode’s Uranograpahie; but he had not— I found there however a new French Astronomical Work by Biot— In the Evening I finished reading the Volume upon Comets, published at Boston, and sent me by Judge Davis— Mr Lewis and Mr Slade passed the latter part of the Evening here; but I did not see them— Received a Notification for a Court to-morrow

18. IV:15. The morning was cold; about -15 of Reaumur, but perfectly clear. I went out on the Square to observe the positions of some of the Stars— The great Bear was as nearly as possible in the Zenith, and I remarked very distinctly all the Stars of the little Bear. I found that the Constellation under which I have for several days observed Jupiter, and which I had taken for Libra, was the Lion. The Calendar marks Jupiter, as being in the Virgin, and I had not recollected the difference between the Signs and the Constellations of the Zodiac— I ascertained by La Lande’s lines Arcturus and Lyra, but missed several others— I went out again before Breakfast and saw the Sun rise quite clear, and he has now reached the extreme of his Southern Declination. I remarked also the Moon’s approach to him, it being now the fourth day before the Conjunction— I was in hopes of seeing her to the last day of her being visible; but the sky clouded up again in the course of the day, and I shall not see her again untill after the change.— It was however still clear enough this Evening to shew me Mars in the Meridian, and the Constellation of Aries, with the first star of the antient Equinox— My Observations abridged much of my reading— I had a morning visit from Mr Montréal— At noon I attended with Mr Smith at the Palace, where the Empresses held a Court, it being the festival of St: Nicholas— The Grand-Duke Nicholas was however not present, being confined with a fever.— The Duke de Serra-Capriola told me it was his son’s fête, and he should be glad to see his friends this Evening, though he gave no invitation— We accordingly all went, after Mrs Adams and I had paid a short visit to Prince Kurakin. The Prince told me of a total change of Ministry in France—the Duke de Vicence Minister of foreign Affairs, and the Duke de Bassano, back in the Office of Minister Secretary of State— The Prince said that the Minister Secretary of State was liable to be called upon by the Emperor every moment of the day; and when the Duke of Bassano had been removed from that Office to the Department of foreign Affairs, he told him the Prince, that he was very glad of the change, because he should no longer be “à la sonnette”— But now he is à la sonnette again. The Grand Juge Règnier, and two or three other Officers are also removed— And the allied troops have taken Stade— We found at the Duke’s a company of at least two hundred persons; very miscellaneous— I came home just before one in the morning, leaving the rest of the family there— They stayed to supper, and came home about four, leaving the company still dancing.— The Princess Amelia of Baden was there.

19. VIII:30. Read prayers for the fourth Sunday in Advent, and Massillon’s Sermon for that day; on the Dispositions suitable for the Communion— It is very long and not among the best. It would seem rather to deter his hearers from partaking of the Communion, than to encourage them to it.— There is so rigorous a view of the Dispositions essential to a profitable communion, and such terrors held out to those who presume to communicate without them that a believer of the Bishop’s doctrine would be apt to prefer omitting it, rather than incur the risk of committing by taking it an atrocious crime, while intending to discharge a duty. I also read his Paraphrase of the 9th: Psalm, in two Parts— The first is a dreadful imprecation against heretics.— He calls upon the deity and says, if they will obstinately persevere in error, repandez sur leurs villes et sur leurs peuples la mort et la désolation; frappez les de ces Calamités qui ont rappellé autrefois à la penitence les Nations les plus criminelles—and a whole page of the same tenor— His master would have said to him— Ye know not what spirit ye are of— The second part of the Paraphrase is confined to disquisition concerning the apparent and temporary prosperity of the wicked, and is rational— The Bishop was a man of exemplary virtue, and of an amiable temper; but he could not shake off the persecuting Spirit of his Church.— Charles read and wrote, and I examined him with regard to his progress in Arithmetic, which is not so good as I could wish— In his writing he continues to improve.

20. IV. But the skies are again invisible, and I am deprived of the opportunity of observing any of their movements. I read in La Lande’s Abridgment untill Nine, and then took Charles to school. Thence I went to Weyher’s, and brought home with me Biot’s Astronomie Physique, which as an Elementary Treatise may be useful to me— As I was taking my walk before dinner, I stopped at Demuth’s Hotel, and saw Mr de Tracy— Mr Montreal had told me on Saturday that he was sick— He has indeed been two or three days very ill, but is now quite recovered— He mentioned having received a letter from his father written since he knew him to be here at St: Petersburg.— Miss Frederica Bode dined with us— In the Evening I went and passed an hour with Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard— Mrs Adams and Mrs Smith spent the latter part of the Evening at Countess Colombis.

21. IV.45. The day of the Winter Solstice; but neither Sun nor Stars to be seen— After reading three hours in La Lande’s Abridgment, I walked one hour before Breakfast— Mr Montreal called upon me, and engaged to transact an affair for me, but missed it. I gain nothing, and have lost much by waiting. Walked again before dinner, but could neither read nor write in the Evening. This portion of the day weighs very heavily upon me.

22. III.45. About an hour earlier than I intended, and I had this day an attack of Rhumatism— My Steward Pierre Ouvré was taken with a violent fever, which confines and disables him— Dr Galloway saw him this Evening— I continued reading La Lande’s Abridgment and La Croix’s Arithmetic and Algebra.— The first of these is the shortest and completest Elementary Treatise on the subject that I have met with— In the Algebra I very soon got beyond my depth, and am not qualified to judge of it.— The Arithmetic includes that of the fractions, but not the extraction of the Roots.— I returned this Evening to the fractions, as preparatory for the Algebra. Received and answered a Note from Mr Montréal.— I wander over La lande’s pages with very little profit, for want of the mathematical knowledge.

23. VI.30. Having by Dr Galloway’s prescription taken a foot-bath last Evening, and being directed by him not to go out this morning, I rose an hour and a half later than my time, and continued my reading of La Lande— Received a note from Mr Montreal, and sent him what he requested— We had company to dinner, The Duke and Duchess of Serra Capriola, and their daughter— His son sent an excuse, being unwell— Chevalier Bardaxi-Azara, and his Lady, Miss Carnerero, Captain Lema, and Captain Parada, General Betancourt, his Lady and two daughters, Countess de Bruges; the Count was unwell and sent an excuse— Countess Colombi, and her sisters Frederica, and Clementine Bode, Don Francisco Colombi, and Mr Zea-Bermudéz, Messrs: Gallatin and his Son, Bayard, Harris, Milligan and Todd; we sat down 28 at table— Pierre is confined to his bed by a violent fever, and we sent for Mr Harris’s Valet de Chambre, who attended in his stead— The Company all retired about 9 in the Evening, very soon after we rose from dinner. I sat between the Duchess and Madame Bardaxi— The former is a Russian Lady, daughter of the old Princess Wäsemsky, and a very intelligent person; Madame Bardaxi is under 30, and speaks very little else than Spanish.

24. IV. The Emperor’s Birth-day— Mr Montreal called upon me this morning, and finished the transaction he had undertaken for me. At Noon I went with Mr Smith to the Palace, where after a Te Deum for the taking of Dresden, Stettin, and Pampoluna the Empresses held a Court— The reigning Empress has received an invitation from the Emperor to go to him, and is to depart next Friday morning. Mrs: Adams went out this Evening to see the illuminations, which were unusually splendid.

25. VI. Dined at Count Romanzoff’s, with one of his large diplomatic Companies of 65 persons— Lord Walpole made him wait for dinner, about half an hour after all the rest of the Company was assembled— I was seated at table between the Minister of the interior Mr Kosodavleff, and Mr Bayard, who complains much of the effect of the Neva-Water upon his health. He told me that he believed Mr Gallatin had been promised the mission here, whether the Extraordinary Mission should succeed or not— His reason for this conjecture was that when they first arrived here Mr Gallatin had seriously commenced the study of the Russian Language, which he had abandoned immediately after being informed of the decision of the Senate upon his nomination. Mr: de Tracy passed the first part of the Evening with us, and Mrs Adams the latter part of it at Countess Colombi’s where she unexpectedly found there was a Ball, in Don Francisco’s apartments.— Dr Galloway sat with me an hour this morning, conversing upon topics of literature— He told me that the English translation of Goguet’s Origin of Laws was by Dr Henry, the author of the History of England, who was an old and intimate friend of his— He said further that Goguet’s work as he believed had given Henry the idea of the plan upon which he had composed the History of England; which is very probable.

26. V:30. Read prayers for St: Stephen’s day, and Massillon’s Christmas Sermon: together with his paraphrase of the 11th. Psalm. The Christmas Discourse does not altogether satisfy the expectation which the occasion, and the character of the preacher, would have led me to form— He touches upon the object of Christ’s Mission, glory to God, and Peace on Earth, but views both parts of the subject on a scale too limited— I also continued reading La Lande, and heard Charles read in the French Bible. Mrs Bayley the English Consul’s Lady paid a visit to Mrs: Adams, and in the Evening had a visit from the young Duke of Serra-Capriola.

27. VI. In the course of the last Night there was a great and sudden change in the weather; from 2 degrees of thawing to 15 of frost; by Reaumur—and after an interval of eight days, during which neither Sun, Moon, nor Stars have been visible, this morning the atmosphere cleared away; the Sun appeared the whole day;—at four in the afternoon I saw from my windows the moon and Venus nearly in conjunction, and the sky was as clear as I ever saw it here— But while I was looking to trace some of the Constellations by La Lande’s linear directions, the usual veil of vapours arose and in ten minutes time overspread the horizon— There was nothing further to be seen— The last time that I saw the former Moon was the fourth day before the change— This is the fifth day of the New Moon— The whole period of the Solstice has also passed away without shewing the Sun’s face. I took Charles this morning to school, and walked home— Went out again, to the shops just before dinner, for household affairs to which Pierre’s illness compels me to attend— He is severely ill, with a violent fever. Dr Galloway was here this day twice to see him.

28. IV:30. I went again early this morning to the shops, and walked before dinner— Reaumur at -15. and no Sun visible. Mr Lewis spent the latter part of the Evening here, but I had finished mine before he came— La Lande and La Croix occupy and amuse me so much that I neglect other objects more important— The rule of not too much is essential to all things, but I have not learnt to observe it— My correspondence is running in arrears.— In the perusal of La Croix’s books I find occasionally useful things which I ought to have known these thirty years. Yesterday and this day I found the rule for calculating the progressive increase of compound interest or of population by a single operation with logarithms, which to me was entirely new.

29. III. That is two hours earlier than I should have wished to rise— But after once waking in the morning, I cannot sleep again and am so restless in bed that I am obliged to rise— I had seven hours of time to occupy untill Breakfast, which I did principally with writing. The weather, was too bad for walking— I finished reading La Lande’s Abridgment of Astronomy, and took up the first Volume of Biot’s Astronomie Physique— La Lande has added very little to my information, but like Schubert has excited my curiosity, to enquire further.— I also gave a couple of hours this day to La Croix, but from the time of Sunset, which is now a quarter before 3. P.M. the day finishes for me to all useful purposes— In the Evening I can do nothing.

30. IV:30. After two hours of watching.— Yesterday at 4 in the afternoon, Reaumur’s thermometer was at -14. This morning when I rose it was at 0. barely the freezing point— It fell constantly the whole day, and at 9 this Evening was at -16.— This Evening the sky became once more clear— Mr Lewis called on me this morning, and brought me a letter which had been enclosed to him from Lisbon for me— It was from the Secretary of State; and dated 16. June last.— I had written to him this morning— I also received letters from Mr Speyer and Mr Hall at Gothenburg mentioning the arrival of the Neptune there.— The letters which I wrote yesterday and this morning have shortened the days, and as the year closes I employed some time in sorting and arranging my papers.

31. VI. Reaumur at -16 this morning and at -22 at nine O’Clock this Evening— A clear sky the whole day— I wrote to Mr Fulton this morning, and walked only before dinner— The brightness of the moon obscured the stars so that I made no new discovery— Mr Harris called upon me and mentioned Mr Gallatin’s intention of going away in a week or ten days; Mr Bayard’s intention being to remain here some time longer— Mr Gallatin goes to Germany; perhaps to Switzerland, taking Frankfort on the Mein in his way. He goes to meet some of his relations who are coming from Geneva to meet him. Mr Bayard’s intention is to order the Neptune to Falmouth in England where he goes to join her— Mr Todd likewise paid me a morning visit, and requested me to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport; he and Coll: Milligan are going to England by the way of Sweden, and propose to leave the City next Monday— I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting the Passport.— Mr Todd had seen the Empress take her departure— She went at half-past two this afternoon, from the
Cazan Church where she had been to perform her devotions on commencing her journey.— There had been a Court at which she had taken leave of the Empress-Mother, and the Russian Nobility; but the foreign Ministers were not summoned to attend.

Day. I have marked during the course of this Month my rising hour every Morning, and it has varied from three to half-past eight— This has been on my part involuntary, my wish being to rise regularly at five. By some constitutional infirmity, I am habitually so much overpowered by drowsiness from the moment of rising from dinner that I am utterly disqualified for any useful occupation, and at the same time subject to waking at almost every hour of the Night, and from the moment of waking equally unable to sleep again; and so restless that I am compelled to rise from bed— My efforts to conquer these propensities have now been more than two years continued and are still ineffectual.— The distribution of my time is in general the same that it has been these two years, but during this Month I have read more and written less than for some preceding time— My attention having been turned to Mathematical Sciences I have read Schubert and La Lande’s Abridgment, and began upon Biot—also La Croix’s Arithmetic, and part of his Algebra. My attempts to acquire some knowledge by observation of the topography of the skies have been constantly baffled by the nature of the atmosphere in this climate and Season, as well as by the want of instruments and Charts— I hope however by persevering attention to make better progress in observation hereafter.

At the close of another year, I renew to the Supreme Creator of the world, my offering of thanksgiving for the blessings which his Providence has dispensed from the time when he gave me being, and particularly for those of the expiring year—my offering of resignation to the afflictive dispensations with which he has been pleased to visit me and my family, and especially in the decease of my beloved and only Sister—and my offering of humble and fervent prayer for his gracious goodness in future to my aged Parents, to my infant children to the partner of my life to my only surviving brother, to all who are near and dear to them, to my friends, my Country and Mankind.
